items.content_html: On the road today for college visits with my senior. For Day 6 of Black History Month, I edited the Wikipedia page of a college we toured last semester which had the wrong year for its integration and did not list student names.

items.content_html: For Day 4 of Black History Month, I made some edits to the Barbara Jordan entry on Wikipedia, including a reference to a speech she once gave at Rice.
items.content_text: For Day 4 of Black History Month, I made [some edits](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Barbara_Jordan&action=history) to the [Barbara Jordan](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barbara_Jordan) entry on Wikipedia, including a reference to [a speech she once gave at Rice](https://updates.wcaleb.org/2024/06/14/barbara-jordan-at.html).

items.content_html: My woodworking dad surprised me by making this unnerving likeness of Feathers McGraw for my office. I initially placed him where my back would be turned to him, but decided that would be a bad idea.
items.content_text: My woodworking dad surprised me by making this unnerving likeness of [Feathers McGraw](https://wallaceandgromit.fandom.com/wiki/Feathers_McGraw) for my office. I initially placed him where my back would be turned to him, but decided [that would be a bad idea](https://www.vulture.com/article/wallace-and-gromit-the-story-behind-feather-mcgraws-return.html).

items.title: The Augusta Parade Ground
items.content_html:
Today I spent longer than I care to admit trying to locate precisely the “parade ground” in Augusta, Georgia, where local African Americans and USCT troops staged a celebration of the Fourth of July in 1865.

I finally found it on this 1872 bird’s eye map, next to what is now known as Magnolia Cemetery on the present-day site of May Park.

The parade ground was developed by the Augusta city council as a city park on the eve of the Civil War, and you can track that development in the local newspaper at the time. But what threw me off for a long time was the presence of a federal arsenal outside of Augusta (on the other side of town). It also had a parade ground. Just not the parade ground I was looking for.
items.content_text:
Today I spent longer than I care to admit trying to locate precisely the "parade ground" in Augusta, Georgia, where local African Americans and USCT troops staged [a celebration of the Fourth of July](https://catalog.hathitrust.org/Record/102898175) in 1865.

I finally found it on [this 1872 bird's eye map](https://www.augustamuseum.org/Collections/item3232), next to what is now known as [Magnolia Cemetery](https://www.augustaga.gov/352/Magnolia) on the present-day site of [May Park](https://www.augustaga.gov/facilities/facility/details/May-Park-92).

The parade ground was developed by the Augusta city council as a city park on the eve of the Civil War, and you can track that development in the local newspaper at the time. But what threw me off for a long time was the presence of a federal arsenal outside of Augusta (on the other side of town). [It also had a parade ground.](https://dp.la/item/ef6a67d27bf65bea8c63f6bebd18d8c1) Just not the parade ground I was looking for.

items.content_html: Reading the obituary of Thomas Gaither prompted me to do some editing on Wikipedia. I added his co-leadership of a March 1960 student civil rights march in Orangeburg, SC, to the background section on the 1968 Orangeburg Massacre.
items.content_text: Reading [the obituary of Thomas Gaither](https://www.nytimes.com/2025/01/24/us/thomas-gaither-dead.html) prompted me to do [some editing on Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Orangeburg_Massacre&diff=prev&oldid=1272006585). I added his co-leadership of a March 1960 student civil rights march in Orangeburg, SC, to the background section on [the 1968 Orangeburg Massacre](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Orangeburg_Massacre).
